This course analyzes the formation and conduct of foreign policy in the United State. The course combines three elements: a study of the history of American foreign relations, an analysis of the causes of American foreign policy such as the international system, public opinion, and the media, and a discussion of the major policy issues in contemporary U.S. foreign policy, including terrorism, civil wars, and economic policy.
Students claimed that this was their favorite IR class. They loved the material covered in the class; they found the lectures and readings “stimulating” and “interesting."

Students heaped praised upon Professor Horowitz. One described his teaching style as “clear” and “straight-forward”. 

This course is meant for both majors and non-majors alike. Even though some people thought there was too much reading, most found the readings very interesting and relevant to the course.
